doc.headline: 6th co-defendant surrenders in O.J. Simpson armed robbery case

text.p: A sixth man sought in the armed robbery case against O.J. Simpson has surrendered in court.

The former professional football star and the men are accused of bursting into a hotel room last week displaying guns, and stealing autographed footballs and other items from two sports memorabilia collectors.
Charles Bruce Ehrlich was taken into custody in Las Vegas after a brief hearing before a judge who set his bail at $32,000 (euro22,777).
Ehrlich faces the same charges as another defendant, Charles Cashmore, who was arraigned minutes earlier on charges including kidnapping, armed robbery and assault with a deadly weapon.
Authorities allege that the suspects went to the hotel room on the pretext of brokering a deal with Alfred Beardsley, an accuser along with Bruce Fromong.
According to police reports, the collectors were ordered at gunpoint to hand over items valued at as much as $100,000 (euro71,179).
Beardsley, an ex-convict, was arrested Wednesday at a Las Vegas hotel on a warrant alleging he violated parole travel restrictions by traveling to Nevada. He remained held without bail.
Fromong, 53, is recovering from a heart attack in a Los Angeles hospital.
